column1: Iquique (Spanish pronunciation: [iˈkike]) is a port city and commune in northern Chile
column2: capital of both the Iquique Province and Tarapacá Region. It lies on the Pacific coast
column3: west of the Pampa del Tamarugal
column4: which is part of the Atacama Desert. It had a population of 191
column5: 468 according to the 2017 census. It is also the main commune of Greater Iquique. The city developed during the heyday of the saltpetre mining in the Atacama Desert in the 19th century. Once a Peruvian city with a large Chilean population
column6: it was conquered by Chile in the War of the Pacific (1879–1883). Today it is one of only two free ports of Chile
column7: the other one being Punta Arenas

column1: Although the city was founded in the 16th century
column2: there is evidence of habitation in the area by the Chango people as early as 7
column4: Iquique was part of the Viceroyalty of Peru as much of South America was at the time
column5: and remained part of Peruvian territory until the end of the 19th century. Iquique's early development was due in large part to the discovery of mineral riches
column6: particularly the presence of large deposits of sodium nitrate in the Atacama Desert (then part of Peruvian territory).

column1: The city has been devastated by several earthquakes

column1: Territorial disputes between Bolivia and Chile triggered the War of the Pacific in 1879. The Battle of Iquique was fought in the harbor of Iquique on May 21
column4: an annual public holiday in Chile. The outcome of the war gave Chile this portion of the Peruvian territory.

column1: Over the years there was substantial emigration from other parts of Chile to this area which was called the Norte Grande. In subsequent years the further exportation of Chilean saltpeter (mainly to European countries) significantly helped in the development of the city
column2: attracting foreigners and rapidly expanding housing projects.
the city was marred by the Santa María de Iquique Massacre when the Chilean Army
column3: under the command of Gen. Roberto Silva Renard
column4: opened fire on thousands of saltpeter miners
column6: who assembled inside the Santa María School. The workers had marched into town to protest their working conditions and wages. Somewhere between 500 and 2
column7: 000 people were killed. The folk group Quilapayún recorded an album in remembrance of the event (Cantata Santa María de Iquique) in 1970. In December 2007 a series of cultural and ceremonial activities were planned
column8: culminating in the week between December 14 to 21
column9: to commemorate the centenary year of the massacre.

column2: Iquique is a third-level administrative division of Chile administered by a municipal council
column3: headed by an alcalde who is directly elected every four years. The 2012–2016 alcalde is Jorge Soria.Within the electoral divisions of Chile
column4: Iquique is represented in the Chamber of Deputies by Mrs. Marta Isasi (Ind.) and Mr. Hugo Gutiérrez (PC) as part of the 2nd electoral district
column5: which includes the entire Tarapacá Region.The commune is represented in the Senate by Fulvio Rossi Ciocca (PS) and Jaime Orpis Bouchon (UDI) as part of the 1st senatorial constituency (Arica and Parinacota Region and Tarapacá Region).

column2: about a thousand East Indian (from India and Pakistani) saltpeter mine workers hired by British mine companies appeared in Iquique and today
column3: their descendants mixed into the local population. Lately
column4: a wave of North American and Australian immigrants came to retire and enjoy the city's beach climate. Immigrants currently correspond to 9.2% of the total population.

column1: Iquique has a rare desert climate (Köppen BWh) with low extremes of temperatures all year round and almost no rainfall. Being characterized by abundant cloudiness
column2: it is sometimes classified as BWn
column3: indicating a coastal desert climate with abundant cloudiness as the n denotes a climate with frequent fog. It is common for this place to almost have no rainy days in a year. It is one of the driest cities in the world

column1: Iquique is served by Diego Aracena International Airport (Spanish: Aeropuerto Internacional Diego Aracena) (IATA: IQQ
column2: ICAO: SCDA). The airport is on the Pacific coast 48 kilometres (30 mi) south of the city.

column1: Iquique is home to football team Deportes Iquique. It hosted the 2016 FIRS Women's Roller Hockey World Cup.
